+.Definition: The plus operator adds two numeric values together or concatenates strings.

-.Definition: The minus operator subtracts one numeric value from another or negates a number.

*.Definition: The multiplication operator multiplies two numeric values.

/.Definition: The division operator divides one numeric value by another.

%.Definition: The modulus operator returns the remainder after division.

++.Definition: The increment operator {c:keyword}"++"{/c} increases a numeric value by one.

--.Definition: The decrement operator {c:keyword}"--"{/c} decreases a numeric value by one.

=.Definition: The assignment operator {c:keyword}"="{/c} assigns the value on the right to the variable on the left.

+=.Definition: The addition assignment operator adds a value to a variable and stores the result back in that variable.

-=.Definition: The subtraction assignment operator subtracts a value from a variable and stores the result back in that variable.

*=.Definition: The multiplication assignment operator multiplies a variable by a value and stores the result back in that variable.

/=.Definition: The division assignment operator divides a variable by a value and stores the result back in that variable.

%=.Definition: The modulus assignment operator applies the remainder operation and stores the result back in the variable.

&=.Definition: The bitwise AND assignment operator applies a bitwise AND and stores the result back in the variable.

|=.Definition: The bitwise OR assignment operator applies a bitwise OR and stores the result back in the variable.

^=.Definition: The bitwise XOR assignment operator applies a bitwise exclusive OR and stores the result back in the variable.

<<=.Definition: The left shift assignment operator shifts bits to the left and stores the result back in the variable.

>>=.Definition: The right shift assignment operator shifts bits to the right and stores the result back in the variable.

>>>=.Definition: The unsigned right shift assignment operator shifts bits to the right without preserving the sign bit.

&.Definition: The bitwise AND operator compares the bits of two values and keeps only the bits that are set in both.

|.Definition: The bitwise OR operator compares the bits of two values and keeps the bits that are set in either value.

^.Definition: The bitwise XOR operator compares the bits of two values and keeps the bits that are different.

~.Definition: The bitwise NOT operator flips all the bits of a value. Zeros become ones and ones become zeros.

<<.Definition: The left shift operator moves the bits of a value to the left by a specified amount.

>>.Definition: The right shift operator moves the bits of a value to the right while preserving the sign bit.

>>>.Definition: The unsigned right shift operator moves the bits of a value to the right without preserving the sign bit.

!.Definition: The logical NOT operator reverses a Boolean value. True becomes false, and false becomes true.

&&.Definition: The logical AND operator returns true only if both conditions are true. It stops evaluating as soon as one condition is false.

||.Definition: The logical OR operator returns true if at least one condition is true. It stops evaluating as soon as a true condition is found.

<.Definition: The less-than operator checks whether the value on the left is smaller than the value on the right.

>.Definition: The greater-than operator checks whether the value on the left is larger than the value on the right.

<=.Definition: The less-than-or-equal operator checks whether the left value is smaller than or equal to the right value.

>=.Definition: The greater-than-or-equal operator checks whether the left value is larger than or equal to the right value.

==.Definition: The equality operator checks whether two values are equal. It returns true if they match.

!=.Definition: The inequality operator checks whether two values are not equal. It returns true when they differ.

...Definition: The range operator represents a range of values between two indices. It is commonly used with arrays and spans.

=>.Definition: The lambda operator separates parameters from the body of a lambda expression. It defines an inline function.

..Definition: The member access operator {c:keyword}"."{/c} is used to access members such as methods, properties, or fields of the preceeding type or object.

?..Definition: The null-conditional operator safely accesses a member only if the value is not null. It prevents null reference errors.

::.Definition: The namespace alias qualifier {c:keyword}"::"{/c} accesses a member through a specific alias. It is commonly used with global or using aliases.

??.Definition: The null-coalescing operator {c:keyword}"??"{/c} returns a fallback value when the left value is null.

??=.Definition: The null-coalescing assignment operator {c:keyword}"??="{/c} assigns a value only if the variable is currently null.

->.Definition: The pointer member access operator accesses a member through a pointer. It is used in unsafe code.
